S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> I think we are talking about three different
> things:
> 
> * Availability
> * Representation
> * Personalization
> 
> I think Availability and Representation are
> RESTful because there is an automatic way to get
> from a URI to a resource via availability and
> representation negotiations (aka 40x responses and
> accept- headers).
> 
> I think personalization is unRestful because there
> is no way to negotiate automatically to a
> particular resource from a URI.

You're presuming that each personalized representation is its own 
resource. That's the point that Walden is trying to get across. The 
Slashdot home page is the Slashdot home page whether it is in English or 
French (presuming that Slashdot was not totally US-centric), whether the 
user has asked Google to turn off images or not, whether the user has 
asked Google to use a blue background or a red one.

True, I cannot send you a URL and have you see Slashdot exactly the same 
way I do. If this is important then Slashdot could generate "view" URLs 
that always returns the same view. But this is clearly not important for 
Slashdot so they don't bother.

One issue with the Web is that people tend not to be explicit about what 
resource the URI represents so you are left to guess about the 
universality and longevity of a representation you are looking at. You 
could imagine an interface that would allow end-users to generate a 
URI/resource with the capabilities you want:

"I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page as it was three seconds ago 
with my personalization applied (no matter who the user is)."

versus

"I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page with the latest stories on it 
and my personalization applied (no matter who the user is)."

versus

"I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page with the latest stories on it 
and the user's personalization applied."

This is probably overkill for 99% of all web sites so it isn't common. 
But it shows how to address this personalization versus universality 
issue. Just make some resources personalized and some universal.

  Paul Prescod
